definition:
Let $X$ be a set. Let ${\rm Sym}(X)$ be the set of permutations of $X$
(i.e. the set of bijective functions from $X$ to itself). Then the act
of taking the composition of two permutations induces a group structure
on ${\rm Sym}(X)$. We call this group the [*symmetric group*]{}.

The group ${\rm Sym}(\{1,2,\ldots, n\})$ is often denoted $S_n$ or
$\mathfrak{S}_n$.

$S_n$ is generated by the transpositions
$\{(1,2),(2,3),\ldots,(n-1,n)\}$, and by any pair of a 2-cycle and
$n$-cycle.

$S_n$ is the Weyl group of the $A_{n-1}$ root system (and hence of the
special linear group $SL_{n-1}$).
